bib.title: Measurements of isomeric cross-sections for (n,alpha) reaction on 144-Sm isotope for neutrons around 14 MeV.

free_txt: I.A.Reyhancan
A.Durusoy
Data table.
SAMES T-400 Neutron Generator in
combination with a Fast Sample Transfer System (FSTS),
which can deliver the sample from the irradiation
position to HpGe detector or vice versa within 0.5 s.
M.M.
Cyclic activation formula was used.
Self-absorption corrections .
Low-energy-neutron contribution- up to 10 %.
Attenuation of the gamma rays in a beta absorber.
Dead time.
or neutron flux monitoring.
Gamma counting system with HpGe detector
(Canberra, 82 cm3, 1.79 keV FWHM at 1333 keV), see
REL-REF of Subasi+,1996.
NE102A scintillation detector for neutron flux
determination . Calibrated by Al(2)O(3) sample.
High-resolution gamma-ray spectrometer was used to
measure gamma activity induced in the Al pellet.
Total error 21.5-47.2%) includes errors due to:
Sample weight,
Concentration of the element,
Isotopic abundance,
Counting solid angle and intrinsic efficiency
of the gamma detector,
Statistical uncertainty (full energy
photo-peak area),
Neutron flux fluctuation,
Effective neutron flux ( including reference
cross section),
Irradiation, cooling and measuring times.
The uncertainties were assumed to be uncorrelated,
the total uncertainties in the cross section values
could be determined by adding the experimental errors
and the uncertainties of nuclear data into the
quadratic function.
SAMES T-400 Neutron Generator in
combination with a Fast Sample Transfer System (FSTS),
which can deliver the sample from the irradiation
position to HpGe detector or vice versa within 0.5 s.
H-3(D,N)He-4 reaction . deuteron beam current
300 microA, accelerating voltage 250 kV.
At the irradiation place (70 mm from neutron source),
neutron fluxes are measured to be from 0.9E+7 to 1.6E+7
n/cm2/s, depending on the neutron target condition.
Six different positions around the target
holder inclined at 45 deg were used. The angles of
the irradiation positions along the deuteron beam were
0, 30, 60, 120, 130 deg,which correspond to the neutron
respectively. The effective energies of the incident
neutrons at each sample position were determined by the
ratios of 90Zr(n,2n)89Zr (3.27 d) (Pavlik+, 1982) and
93Nb(n,2n)92mNb (10.15 d) (Nethaway, 1978) reaction
cross sections (the Zr/Nb ratio method) (Lewis+, 1980)
and procedure of the energy measurement is given in
detail in Subasi+(1996).
Acrylic plate of 10 mm thickness was placed in front of
the detector to protect samples from beta particles.
and to minimize the photon absorption and production
bremsstrahlung.
90Zr(n,2n)89Zr c-s data used in ZR/Nb method.
93Nb(n,2n)92mNb c-s data used in ZR/Nb method
Zr/Nb ratio method .
Details of Zr/Nb method.
Sample pellets of 13 mm diameter, 8.5 mm thickness,
about 2 g weight were pressed from the natural,
high-purity (99.9%) Sm(2)O(3), and Al2O3 powders.
Water contents in the samples were removed by heating
the oxide materials up to 105 deg C, then they were
kept in a desiccator for 0.5 h to cool down to the room
temperature; next they were filled into dry stainless
steel capsules and pressed to form a dense pellet; the
pellets were tightly packed into thin polyethylene
boxes and sealed-off.
Data of Sm-144(n,2n)Sm-143m .
Theoretical calculations by Talys 1.2.
Decay data from J.K.Tuli, Nuclear Wallets Cards(2005)
and R.B.Firestone+, Table of Isotopes: CD-ROM Edition
1.0. John Wiley and Sons Ltd., London(1996).
Error of half-life value given under
DECAY-DATA .
Isotopic abundance (3.07+-0.07) % .
Tables I (monitor), IV of J,NSE,174,202,2013.
